docs.lead_paragraph: Allowing a test-tube baby to mature just a bit more before implanting the embryo in the mother's womb may improve a couple's chances of having a baby, doctors reported today. The increasingly popular test-tube technique known as in vitro fertilization involves taking an egg from a woman and sperm from a man and fertilizing the egg in a laboratory dish instead in the body.

headline.main: Time Lends Hand to Test-Tube Fertilization

docs.abstract: Doctors, writing in Fertility and Sterility, journal of American Society for Reproductive Medicine, say that allowing test-tube baby to mature just a bit more before implanting embryo in mother's womb may improve a couple's chances of having baby (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Cruise ships, contained and often immune to law enforcement, are a rape victim's worst nightmare (''Cruise Line Discloses Sexual Assault Cases,'' Week in Review, July 18).
docs.abstract: Dr Natalie Roche letter cautions that cruise ships, contained and often immune from the law, are rape victim's worst nightmare (July 18 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Cruise ships, contained and often immune to law enforcement, are a rape victim's worst nightmare (''Cruise Line Discloses Sexual Assault Cases,'' Week in Review, July 18).

docs.lead_paragraph: The real-life weekday romance called ''A Wedding Story'' follows a formula as tried and true as the marriage rite itself: man and woman fall in love, put on fancy clothes and publicly declare their devotion. The only difference here is that the entire proceeding, from proposal to vow, is witnessed by more than a million viewers who have made the show one of the most popular in the eight-year history of the Learning Channel. Since it began in 1996, the half-hour show has featured the nuptials of more than 200 couples. One episode focused on a pair of young doctors recounting their storybook courtship before exchanging vows inside a castle strewn with flowers. In another, classmates from high school met at a 10-year reunion and soon began dating and planning a giant Italian wedding. Then there was the memorable nuptials of a couple who exchange vows midair at 12,000 feet, after jumping out of a plane accompanied by a minister and entire wedding party.
docs.abstract: Comment on daytime television series A Wedding Story, which has featured nuptials of more than 200 couples since 1996; photo; show is one of most popular in history of Learning Channel (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: JACQUELINE ORTIZ wants to be an actress or a model. Cynthia Infante is also interested in acting, or maybe medicine. Both are 11-year-old Ossining seventh graders who are pursuing their dreams not in acting school but in a program to prevent teen-age pregnancy. With a teen-age pregnancy rate in this village somewhat higher than the county's average, Westchester officials decided that Ossining was a good place to aim an intensive program to cut that rate through education, job services, medical care, counseling and providing each child with an advocate who would, along with their parents, fight for their interests. Thirty low-income black and Hispanic boys and girls are taking part in a three-year, $163,000 Promise Program.
docs.abstract: Article describes intensive program in Ossining, NY, sponsored by Westchester County, aimed at cutting teenage pregnancy rate through education, job services, medical care, counseling and advocacy; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is nothing sleek or high-tech about this third-floor conference room in Fairfax, Va., except, perhaps, the bright red laser pointer that skitters across the eerie greenish slide of phosphorescent sperm. The projector jams periodically during the hourlong presentation, and the central air-conditioning can't keep up with the late-spring heat, so some very low-tech fans are brought in to move the muggy air around in circles. The crowd -- about 40 people, mostly couples, mostly in their mid-30's, nearly all of them paying a baby sitter so they can be here -- shifts and rustles in the hodgepodge of chairs. One very pregnant woman in the second row (planning ahead, for the baby after this one) fans her face with the cardboard information packet, creating a breeze in the most old-fashioned way.
docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin cover article on new technology that allows parents to choose their child's sex; technology allows sperm that carry X chromosomes (which create female embryos) to be separated from sperm that carry Y chromosomes (which create male embryos); process--known and now trademarked as Microsort--has been used in cattle for more than decade; Genetics and IVF Institute, infertility clinic with reputation somewhere between cutting edge and maverick, is the only place in world authorized to use it on humans; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The female condom, seldom used in the West, is catching on here and in many parts of the developing world, slowly becoming an important new weapon in the fight against the AIDS epidemic. Nearly seven million have been distributed in 34 countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America, and the device is gaining acceptance among men as well as women.

headline.main: Condoms for Women Gain Approval Among Africans

docs.abstract: Female condom, seldom used in West, is catching on in South Africa, finding favor with men as well as women, and it is slowly becoming an important new weapon in fight against AIDS epidemic; United Nations AIDS and other organizations working to persuade more women to try the female condom are first approaching prostitutes and other women with multiple partners, since persuading them to use condoms has notably reduced rates of AIDS infection; female condom, properly used, is believed to be as good as or better than the male condom at preventing infection and is slightly less effective than male condom at preventing pregnancy; photo (M)
